content.description: This is a combination crack/face problem, and the climbing seems pretty uniform difficulty with no significant crux. This is a good climb to introduce the area to beginners, since it doesn't require a rappel into the abyss.
content.protection: A standard rack, with emphasis on small to medium stoppers; several draws are needed.
content.location: This climb is accessed from the parking lot. and finding it may be more difficult than the climb! Go to the furthest end of the lot and climb over the fence, down climb a few feet to a wide ledge system. be seen up and left.Follow the ledge until the face can The climb is on a steep, slabby face on the climbers left.

content.description: This is the line shares the start of  Greystoke, moves right and climbs the face to the arete.  There you'll find a bolt that protects the brutal crux move.  Felt hard for the grade. Keep your eye on both sides of the arete as you work your way up.   A couple more bolts and your home free.
content.protection: RPs, small cams, and  3 draws
content.location: From the look out area across from the bathrooms, jump the fence to the left.  The obvious arete to the right of Greystoke. Look for the 3 bolts in the middle of the route. I built a belay with some small nuts and .1 X4.

content.description: Super quality crack on the north side of the bridge.  Fingers and hands, kind of flared, some devious stemming.
content.protection: fingers and hands.
content.location: On the North side of the Bridge.  This is the striking line below the right hand side of the bridge when looking from Dillingham Blues.

content.description: A good climb, but a little harder to get to. The starting traverse makes the first few placements of gear and belay anchor critical if you lead directly from the Hemateria ledge.
content.protection: A rack of fingers to hand-sized gear.
content.location:
As for Hemateria Left...

From the overlook with handrails below the parking lot, walk East 10 meters past the tree-rap for 'B-25' and continue another 10 meters to stop above this climb. You will see a good platform-like ledge down below you, 3/4 of the way to the water and large enough in size to enjoy the belay.

From there, start off by traversing left 7 meters to the base of a good handcrack, 'Stone King (10a).'

content.description: Hand crack immediately climber’s left of Superman. A little dirty but fun.
content.protection: TR or SR

content.description: Great splitter fingers to a hands corner. 10b staying in the splitter or 9+ if you stem out right.
content.protection: Standard rack; nuts; maybe a # 4 near the top.
content.location: At the end of of the fence. (east) You can step across east and see this route below.

content.description: The route folloes a left facing dihedral, by means of a short lieback and then face climbing and stemming. The crux is only a few moves near the start. There are decent holds but pro is sparse. Frequently toproped, along with Mary Ann and Pet Semetary. Possibly the easiest 5.9 in the Bridge Area.
content.protection: Small stoppers and RPs. A light rack will suffice.
content.location: Rap from the second stunted pine past the end of the parking lot, into an alcove. This approach is also used for Mary Ann and Pet Semetary.

content.description: Stemming and fingers. Climber’s right of All Time Loser. Dirty.
content.protection: Small cams. Quite flared.

content.description: Climb has a couple of weird/ interesting moves mixed in with some good hand jams and finger locks at the top.  Reachy for a 5'10'' guy!
content.protection: .5-2 camelots heavy on hand size, maybe a 3, a set of nuts, and some slings to alleviate rope drag.  Some cordelletes could be useful to set up a TR on the pointy knobs at the top of the climb if that's what you're going for.
content.location: Located just east of the bridge before the descent gully.  The climb starts toward the bottom of the canyon just to the right of some faint white paint.  A top-rope can be set up with some static line, but it's a little exposed.  One can lower down to the top from the fence posts if you're nervous about it

content.description: Hand crack; dirty
content.protection: SR
content.location: Two routes climber’s right of All Time Loser

content.description: This is a variation to the finish of Peterman's Route. it stays on the face left of the corner and climbs the cracked face to the rim, starting at the ledge some 40' below the top.
content.protection: Standard rack to hand-size cams.
content.location: Same as Peterman's Route. Either a very short rappel from the handrails or lower by the belayer.

content.description: This route combines climbing on good holds and excellent jamming. The pro is extremely good in solid reddish-brown Precambrian Granite. The route simply follows the line of least resistance up the large left facing corner. The final 30' is rather steep but is on great holds. A fun introduction to Fremont Canyon. Many climbers simply lower down to a large ledge at the base of the final steep corner, and this is frequently toproped by beginners and first-time visitors.
content.protection: Standard widely spaced rack with a few pieces up to 2".
content.location: At the parking lot area there is an overlook fenced off for safety's sake. Facing outward, Peterman's Route, sometimes called Peterman's Corner, is at the right hand corner closest the parking lot. Rappel into the canyon to a ledge a few feet abve water level

content.description: This is a very steep and moderatly "reachy" face climb. It can be more difficult for short climbers. Lead up to the bolt and then  continue up and slightly to the left following good but somewhat widely spaced holds. This is fairly steep at the start, and the difficulty only eases after the first 60 feet. Decent placements for smaller cams exist.
content.protection: Fixed pro consists of one bolt and a fixed piton. Additional pro needed; a standard rack with a few QDs will suffice.
content.location: Rap into a shallow alcove from the second stunted pine tree past the parking lot. Same start as Slim Pickins. Move right about 10-15 feet to the right, faacing the wall to the start of the route. The bolt is an obvious marker.

content.description:
This route starts in an obtuse, blackish dihedral right off the river. Head up the black corner right in front of you, cheating into the OW out right if necessary (I did, my partner did not). Climb up through some easier terrain (~45 ft to this point) and then shoot out left out a leaning, flaring, off-fingers crack to a good stance below a short finger crack in a corner. Muscle your way up this and scramble up some awkward crap to the rails.

Overall, I thought this was a pretty lousy route, but if you've done everything else...
content.protection: Doubles from fingers to #2 camalot.
content.location: Rap from the east end of the handrails, and swing to climber's right until you are directly below the obvious, gaping dihedral.

content.description: Rappel to a ledge below a small (3') roof.  Climb out roof on fingers then continue up the wide crack above.
content.protection: hands/fingers/OW
content.location: North side of Bridge.  Looking from Dillingham Blues; there is an obvious right facing corner (Donkey King 5.8).  Left of this corner is two cracks, the leftmost one is Morning Illness.

content.description: A somewhat nondescript route starting just left of Slim Pickins. This is usually the escape route for those unable to climb Slim Pickins or Pet Semetary. It is a pair of hand/fist cracks that provide decent but dull climbing to the canyon rim.
content.protection: Standard rack up to 2" cams.
content.location: In alcove shared with Slim Pickins. Rap from second stunted tree using a 60 meter rope for a single rope rappel.

content.description:
This may be an existing route, but it’s not listed in the guidebooks, and no one else I’ve spoken with seems to know the name. If you have any information on this route, let me know, I’d love to give proper credit where it’s due. With that said...

This is a fun little moderate! Easy climbing up several sloping ledges to a short but thought provoking headwall.
content.protection:
Hand sized cams, stoppers

Natural anchor

Belay from good ledge above route
content.location:
Just beyond Star Plunge, but not quite to Sun Buttress. You’ll see a thin pinnacle, slightly detached from the proper canyon rim. A small gap must be crossed in order to reach the pinnacle, which is easily done with a bit of scrambling.

Possibly next to Big Dick?(there is a set of bolted anchors about 15ft away above a bolted arete down-river on the pinnacle)

content.description: From the bolt belay, face climb up anthen wake a tricky travers left by a bolt (crux) then up towards a left leaning handcrack that leads to the canyon rim. The final hand crack is awkward and somewhat strenuous, anms well as being poorly protected due to somewhat broken rock. I found the crack exit harder than the "crux" step-across.
content.protection: Light rack with emphasis on RPs, some smaller wires, and cams to 2". Protection is "sparse."
content.location: Use same rappel anchor as Greystoke, but rap into the canyon proper and not the alcove for Greystoke. Rap to a ledge (sloper!) with a single bolt belay anchor. The route lies about 20 feet right (East) from Greystoke.

content.description: The route is strictly great, steep face climbing on widely spaced holds. It starts from the extreme edge of the ledge at climbers right facing the rock. A slippery stem-across is required to become established on the face; the route proceeds upward and then moves left following the sharp-cut holds. There are a few awkward moves up and a long reach left to the final exit ledges. Short, but intense. A very sweet climb. This was (and still is!) a very bold lead when climbed.
content.protection: One bolt. Fence post anchors at top.

content.description: This climb ascends the face above the platform to the right of the 'Hemateria Left' corner. Slightly harder and really not quite as clean.
content.protection: A standard light rack to hands-sized.
content.location:
As for Hemateria Left...

From the overlook with handrails below the parking lot, walk East 10 meters past the tree-rap for 'B-25' and continue another 10 meters to stop above this climb. You will see a good platform-like ledge down below you, 3/4 of the way to the water and large enough in size to enjoy the belay.

content.description: Rap in 60' to this ledge (lower your ropes to keep them dry) and climb back up on the large corner and crack. A good climb overall, but short, even for this area.
content.protection: A standard light rack to fist-sized.
content.location: From the overlook with handrails below the parking lot, walk East 10 meters past the Tree rap for B-25 and continue  another 10 meters to stop above this climb. You will see a good platform-like ledge down below you, 3/4 of the way to the water and large enough in size to enjoy the belay.

content.description: Dihedral. Fingers/hands.
content.protection: Gear
content.location: Pine Tree Area: 150' +/- from the bridge. Rap from the large Pine Tree.

content.description: Climb a steep, flaky face, unprotected for about 20-25 feet to a sloping ramp. Move into the right-facing shallow dihedral and follow it to the rim; primarily face climbing adjacent to the dihedral, which can be used for stemming and an occasional hold on the edge, but the crack in the base takes small pieces. Very continuous climbing, and easy to get pumped trying to place pro. A very nice line on generally excellent rock. Possibly the hardest route I've climbed at Fremont Canyon.
content.protection: Small wires, RPs, and medium nuts; could use small cams up to a #1 Camalot and smaller tricams.
content.location: Hop the left side of the brown fence at the overlook, walk left past the short bit of talus. Just after the talus there is a 2 bolt anchor next to a small bush. Rappel into the canyon to a ledge at the water's edge, a 110 foot rappel.

content.description: Face and lieback with 7 bolts.
content.protection: #3 friend, draws
content.location: 20 feet right of First Blood

content.description: Leaning crack climber’s just left of Carpenter’s Corner.
content.protection: Standard rack

content.description: Flared finger/hand crack
content.protection: Fingers/hands
content.location: On north side of bridge.  When looking from Dillingham Blues; left of bridge.  just right of morning illnesses.  Left of large right facing corner.

content.description: A longer and better route than some in the area. A nice corner with nice climbing. Belay up top can be done from the bolted anchors of 'Gleaming The Cube (12a).'
content.protection: A rack from fingers to fist.
content.location: Walk West back along the canyon wall from the East End of the fence, perhaps 50 meters. Arrange a rap into the steep gully and walk out on rubble to it's Western side. You will see a bolted route, 'Gleaming the Cub (12a)' and a right-facing corner just left of it. THat corner is 'First Blood (10a).'

content.description:
Start at the left base of the rock for the original and easiest line. Move up and right passing a horizontal crack to a high step onto the face with bolt protection. Staying left keeps the route at the original grade of 5.10a, but directly up the bolts is slightly more difficult.

Also very easy to set up a toprope for early season training. Fun!
content.protection: There are 3 bolts on this route. Only need quickdraws.
content.location: Erocktica is on a very large boulder about a hundred yards uphill from the restrooms. From the parking lot entrance go past the Restrooms to the very end of the lot and follow a draw uphill for the easiest approach.

content.description: Off-width and hand crack w/ a fantastic hand jam roof pull.  Easy jamming until the protectable roof.
content.protection: Hands and fist up to a #4 camalot or top-rope
content.location: It's the middle crack of the right hand railing area. You can lower down to a good platform for leading.

content.description: Short flared finger crack between Altered State & Easy Day for a Lady and Going Going Gone & The Nubus.  No ledge or anchor at the start so a little more set up needed if leading (anchor for belayer) - given the length and time hassle leading would take, recommend as a quick end of the day TR....
content.protection: Gear to 2.”

content.description: This is the suprisingly fun right facing dihedral on the north west side of the bridge.  A little offwidth with stemming and face holds.
content.protection: fingers to offwidth size pieces.
content.location: northwest side of the Bridge.  this is the obvious right facing dihedral.

content.description: This is probably the route you came to Fremont for. Pull over a small but insecure roof to an outrageous handcrack with superb position. Unrelenting hands to to thin hands. Rap 85 ft from the bridge to anchors below. The crack just to the right of Dillingham is All Time Loser.
content.protection: Standard rack, emphasis on hands and thin hands.
content.location: Directly underneath the south end of the bridge.

content.description: Dihedral with finger-hand crack.
content.protection: Gear
content.location: The top is 15 feet west of the pine tree

content.description: Start at the same stance as Stone King, but go straight up the flaring finger crack/lieback. Then traverse to the right and go up the face, past two bolts.
content.protection: finger sized and smaller cams
content.location: Two bolt anchor at top, climber's right of the overlook area.

content.description: Step high from a large boulder onto sloping, water polished holds and move up to a more secure stance before any pro is available. A shallow, left facing dihedral constitutes the line to follow; steep crack and face moves are surmounted either by jamming or libacking. Fairly continuous hard climbing leads to the rim. This route may be a sandbag at only 5.9, but is graded according to the local standard. Walk to your car to conclude things.
content.protection: Standard rack, including up to a #3 Camalot.
content.location: This route is nearly under the bridge on the South side of the canyon. Walk down the standard "South Rim Descent" to a point nearly under the bridge. There is a prominent dihedral that constitutes the Bridge route; Bushwacker shares a start with the Bridge Route.

content.description: A good climb in a good corner. Perhaps one of the most accessible routes in the canyon. But on bust weekends, watch out for tourists in the area. Enjoy good jams on good rock on the way back to the top.
content.protection: A standard light rack. A 50 meter rope might be the best to keep your stuff dry when rapping, as you are just above the water, but watch out for the ends!
content.location: To access this route, walk down from the visitor's center and parking lot to the small overlook with handrails. Go East 10 meters to a single tree and rap down into the canyon (80'). The right-facing corner is the climb.

content.description: Absolutely fantastic crack, one of the best in the canyon in my opinion.  Two cruxes, one pulling the roof on big deep hands, then another pulling a section of tight hands a little before the ledge, with great karate chop hands in between.  If you have small hands and/or short arms, the first crux will be especially difficult for you, and just the reverse if you have meathooks.  Sweet route, do it!
content.protection: Plenty of #3 and #3.5 Freinds, and doubles down to #1.  I believe you can aslo stuff a big cam such as an old #4 Camalot or #5 Freind in a pod if you want to lug it around.  That should sew it up.
content.location: Right under the south side of the bridge.  This is the right of the two obvious prominent cracks.
